speaker: Joe Manchin
vclaim: Approximately 20 million Americans have acquired health insurance since the High Cost Care Act in 2010
date: stated on April 17, 2019 in a tweet:
title: Did 20 million Americans get health insurance from the DEA?
text: As the battle for affordable court care continued, Mr. Joe Manchen, D-W.Va., went to Twitter to argue that millions of Americans had benefited from the law. Manchen wrote: "Let's be clear: getting rid of the Affordable Care Act without a plan would be awful for the people of the Western Virgin and the Americans who lived in previous circumstances, and for some 20 million Americans who have acquired health insurance since the Act was passed in 2010. Let us be clear: the repeal of the Affordable Care Act without a plan would be awful for the population of the Western Virgin and the Americans who lived in previous circumstances, and nearly 20 million Americans have acquired health insurance since the Act was passed in 2010. We've had a good look. What does the data show? The Kaiser Foundation for the Family, a non-Royal institution focusing on health-care policy, published data up to 2017 highlighting the Manchen Statement. According to data from the Foundation, since 2010, the number of Americans with health insurance has increased by some 35 million, even higher than the number of Manchens mentioned. However, although the law was passed in 2010, it did not fully enter into force until 2014, so the most accurate year for use as a baseline is 2013. However, the data continue to support Manchin ' s claim. In fact, it's less than the real number. Since 2013, some 26.6 million people have received health insurance. On January 14, 2021, Chuck Grasley stated in a tweet that insulin prices had "lost the RoOOF for patients/taxpayers bc from the manufacturer, a health plan and PBM Biz practices." • On February 2, 2012, it should be noted that the Affordable Care Act, although a major factor in this increase, is not the only one. As the bum generation progresses, an increasing number of Americans turn into guaranteed health care under medical care -- about 10,000 a day. Because of this, some previously uninsured persons will suddenly be counted as insured when they reach the age of 65. For this reason, they have medical care to thank, rather than the Affordable Care Act. In addition, sustained economic recovery has played a role in expanding the pool of insured persons, increasing the number of Americans who were working and as a result were able to secure health insurance through their work. However, there is little question about the role of affordable care law. Between 2008 and 2012 - a period equal to five years before the entry into force of the Health Insurance Act - health insurance received just under 10 million people, well below 26 million between 2013 and 2017. Our ruling Manchen tweeted, "Almost 20 million Americans... have received health insurance since the Affordable Care Act adopted in 2010." Since 2013, the year before the entry into force of the Act, until 2017, the number of Americans with health insurance has increased by 26.6 million, which means that Manchen has underestimated the gains. It should be noted, however, that the gains made in the area of medical care and health care sponsored by the employer are part of this increase and therefore cannot be attributed entirely to the Affordable Care Act. We're mostly assessing this statement right.
